sources.data_found: The Star HPC cluster leverages NVIDIA HGX-based systems with A100 and H100 GPUs, AMD EPYC processors, a resilient storage system with high-speed SSDs, and an ultra-high-throughput, low latency InfiniBand network fabric.
The compute nodes feature high-end H100 and A100 GPUs, AMD EPYC and Intel Xeon processors, and over 7 Terabytes of combined RAM.
The cluster represents a $1.5M investment by Hofstra University and the National Science Foundation.

student_data.notes: Hofstra CS enrollment estimated based on university-wide enrollment data. Total Hofstra enrollment: 10,393 (6,224 undergraduate, 4,169 graduate). The CS department offers BA/BS in CS, BS in Computer Engineering, BS in CS & Math, BS in CS & Cybersecurity at undergraduate level, and MS in Computer Science at graduate level. Based on typical CS department sizes at similar universities (approximately 4% of undergrads, 3.6% of graduate students), estimated CS enrollment is calculated. PhD count estimated based on faculty size (10 full-time faculty per department website) and typical advisor-student ratios. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

gpu_resources.notes: Star HPC cluster confirmed to have NVIDIA HGX-based systems with both A100 and H100 GPUs. Exact node counts and GPUs per node not publicly disclosed. Cluster funded by $1.5M investment from Hofstra University and NSF. System currently in soft launch phase as of the documentation date. HGX-based systems typically have 8 GPUs per node, but specific configuration not confirmed in public documentation.

analysis_notes: Hofstra University has invested significantly in the Star HPC cluster with both H100 and A100 GPUs in HGX-based systems. However, specific node counts and total GPU counts are not publicly available in the documentation found. The cluster serves Hofstra University, Adelphi University, and Nassau Community College through a shared arrangement.
